newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Ariston says committed to Cambodia project.
newsitem.headline: Ariston says committed to Cambodia project.

text.p: The Malaysia-based firm Ariston Sdn Bhd said on Sunday it was committed to executing its $1.3-billion-port development project in Cambodia despite delays and "problems."

"Ariston would like to reiterate that despite problems encountered and delays it will remain committed to complete the project and honour its agreement with the Royal Cambodian Government," Ariston said in a statement from Kuala Lumpur. On Friday, Reuters obtained a letter from co-Premier Prince Norodom Ranariddh to Ariston Chief Executive Officer Chen Lip Keong that said the company's leases for a resort and golf course and airport concession agreement were "null and void."

The letter, dated February 26, said the September 16 agreements had not followed proper legal procedures and had taken on political overtones because they were signed only by a representative of the Cambodian People's Party (CPP).
Ranariddh, who heads the royalist FUNCINPEC party, and co-Premier Hun Sen of the CPP, formed an uneasy coalition after running against each other in national elections in 1993.
Investors have complained that feuds between the two leaders often hurt business, especially when high-profile deals turn political.

Ariston, however, said it remained optimistic about its projects in Cambodia and noted the voided contracts were only sub-packages of its overall $1.3-billion-project to develop the southern port city of Sihanoukville.
It said it had made a good faith effort to have the agreements signed by officials from FUNCINPEC, but that FUNCINPEC representatives had not responded in time to their requests.

Ariston said Ranariddh wanted the project to be completed and had sent a representative to inspect the work site last week. It called Ranarridh a "dynamic leader who wants his country to develop and prosper."
